content.webTitle: Baillie Gifford prize goes to Aids chronicle How to Survive a Plague

fields.headline: Baillie Gifford prize goes to Aids chronicle How to Survive a Plague
fields.bodyText: David France’s account of the Aids epidemic, How to Survive a Plague, has won the Baillie Gifford prize for non-fiction, as chair of judges Sir Peter Bazalgette hailed the importance of serious non-fiction as an “antidote to 140-character culture”. Opening with a quote from Paul Monet, “Grief is a sword, or it is nothing”, France’s book chronicles how the activist community fought to develop the drugs that would turn HIV into a largely treatable condition. It covers the years between 1981 and 1996, when, as France puts it, “there was no effective medical treatment for an HIV infection and death was almost certain”, and how with the founding of Act Up (Aids Coalition to Unleash Power) and TAG (Treatment Action Group), activists paved the way towards a medical breakthrough. France, an investigative reporter and film-maker who has followed the rise of Aids since the beginning of the outbreak, beat titles including Simon Schama’s Belonging and Christopher de Bellaigue’s The Islamic Enlightenment to win the £30,000 award, the UK’s top prize for non-fiction. Bazalgette, the author and chairman of ITV who chaired the judges, said the panel had been looking for books that were “very well-written, engaging and enjoyable, and revelatory – saying something important”. “Here’s a book that works in at least three really interesting ways,” he said of France’s winning title, which draws from his 2012 Oscar-nominated documentary of the same name. “It’s an incredibly visceral, personal story of someone who was a young gay man in the 80s in New York as the Aids epidemic developed. On a wider level it is the story of how society reacted to [the illness], and the enormous prejudice against gay men. And the third really interesting story is the relationship between the gay community and big pharma – the hunt there was to find a palliative, and how David France and his contemporaries became the guinea pigs for the drug companies.” Bazalgette said that France’s book had “so many layers, and is substantial – it’s a really important historical document”. France has also written about the Catholic sexual abuse scandal, in Our Fathers, while his latest film is a documentary about a transgender activist, The Death and Life of Marsha P Johnson. According to Bazalgette, the panel took two hours to pick a winner from a shortlist that also included books from Kapka Kassabova, Daniel Mendelsohn and Mark O’Connell. “Each book on the shortlist of six examined what it means to be human – what it means to be Jewish, to be Muslim, to be an exile, to be a son, to be a father, to be gay,” said Bazalgette, who was joined on the judging panel by the science writer Anjana Ahuja, the tenor and writer Ian Bostridge, academic and writer Sarah Churchwell, and the journalist and broadcaster Razia Iqbal. After working with his fellow judges through more than 150 books, Bazalgette said that non-fiction today was in very healthy condition, and spoke out for its importance in an age of fake news. “These are profound, thoughtful pieces of work, which are all about us now, even when they’re works of history,” he said. “These are serious pieces of work, well-sourced, published by bona fide publishers whom we trust. In a world of wild fabrications, paranoia, rumours and fake news, here is an antidote. These are more than enjoyable reads. It is very important to have these books.” The Baillie Gifford prize, formerly known as the Samuel Johnson award, has been won in the past by, among others, Philippe Sands and Helen Macdonald.
